column2: CHAPTER XXVI
column3: CHAPTER twenty six

column2: THE WINGED VICTORY
column3: THE WINGED VICTORY

column2: KATE turned and placing the baby on the front seat, she knelt and put her arms around the little thing, but her lips only repeated the words: "Praise the Lord for this precious baby!" Her heart was filled with high resolve.
column3: KATE turned and placing the baby on the front seat, she knelt and put her arms around the little thing, but her lips only repeated the words: "Praise the Lord for this precious baby!" Her heart was filled with high resolve.

column2: She would rear the baby with such care.
column3: She would rear the baby with such care.

column2: She would be more careful with Adam.
column3: She would be more careful with Adam.

column2: She would make heroic effort to help him to clean, unashamed manhood.
column3: She would make heroic effort to help him to clean, unashamed manhood.

column2: She would be a better sister to all her family.
column3: She would be a better sister to all her family.

column2: She would be friendlier, and have more patience with the neighbours.
column3: She would be friendlier, and have more patience with the neighbours.

column2: She would join in whatever effort the church was making to hold and increase its membership among the young people, and to raise funds to keep up the organization.
column3: She would join in whatever effort the church was making to hold and increase its membership among the young people, and to raise funds to keep up the organization.

column2: Kate arose with the benediction, picked up the baby, and started down the aisle among the people she had known all her life.
column3: Kate arose with the benediction, picked up the baby, and started down the aisle among the people she had known all her life.

column2: On every side strong hands stretched out to greet and welcome her.
column3: On every side strong hands stretched out to greet and welcome her.

column2: They all knew how she could work, and what she could give if she chose; while that she had stood at the altar and been baptized, meant that something not customary with the Bates family was taking place in her heart.

column2: So they welcomed her, and praised the beauty and sweetness of the baby until Kate went out into the sunshine, her face glowing.

column2: Slowly she walked home and as she reached the veranda, Adam took the baby.

column2: She sang, she laughed, she was unspeakably happy.

column2: It never occurred to Kate that she had done an unprecedented thing.

column2: She had done as her heart dictated. She did not know that she put the minister into a most uncomfortable position, when he followed her request to baptize her and the child. column2: The middle of the week Nancy Ellen came flying up the walk on winged feet, herself.
column3: The middle of the week Nancy Ellen came flying up the walk on winged feet, herself.

column2: She carried photographs of several small children, one of them a girl so like Little Poll that she might have been the original of the picture.

column2: They just came, said Nancy Ellen rather breathlessly.

column2: She's charming! she said.

column2: You'll just put it through, as you do things out here.
column3: You'll just put it through, as you do things out here.

column2: Kate, you are making this place look fine.
column3: Kate, you are making this place look fine.

column2: I used to say I'd rather die than come back here to live, but lately it has been growing so attractive, I've been here about half my time, and wished I were the other half."
column3: I used to say I'd rather die than come back here to live, but lately it has been growing so attractive, I've been here about half my time, and wished I were the other half."

column2: Kate slipped her arm around Nancy Ellen as they walked to the gate.

column2: Usually it's sickness, and sorrow, and losing their friends that bring people to the consolations of the church.

column2: You bore those things like a stoic.

column2: Kate, you make me think of the 'Winged Victory,' this afternoon. If I get this darling little girl, will she make me big, and splendid, and fine, like you?"
column3: Kate, you make me think of the 'Winged Victory,' this afternoon. If I get this darling little girl, will she make me big, and splendid, and fine, like you?"

column2: Kate suddenly drew Nancy Ellen to her and kissed her a long, hard kiss on the lips.
column3: Kate suddenly drew Nancy Ellen to her and kissed her a long, hard kiss on the lips.

column2: Good-bye and good luck to you, and remember me to Robert."
column3: Good bye and good luck to you, and remember me to Robert."

column2: Nancy Ellen stood intently studying the picture she held in her hand. Then she looked at Kate, smiling with misty eyes: "I think, Kate, I'm very close, if I am not really where you are this minute," she said. Then she started her car; but she looked back, waving and smiling until the car swerved so that Kate called after her: "Do drive carefully, Nancy Ellen!"
column3: Nancy Ellen stood intently studying the picture she held in her hand. column2: Kate wanted to tell him of her final visit with Nancy Ellen, but she could not at that time. Robert's aged mother came to him, and said she could remain as long as he wanted her, so that was a comfort to Kate, who took time to pity him, even in her blackest hour.

column2: She could have wailed, and lamented, and relinquished all she had gained, but she did not.

column2: She merely went on with life, as she always had lived it, to the best of her ability when she was so numbed with grief she scarcely knew what she was doing.
column3: She merely went on with life, as she always had lived it, to the best of her ability when she was so numbed with grief she scarcely knew what she was doing.

column2: Every Sabbath, and often during the week, her feet carried her to the cemetery, where she sat in the deep grass and looked at those three long mounds and tried to understand life; deeper still, to fathom death.
column3: Every Sabbath, and often during the week, her feet carried her to the cemetery, where she sat in the deep grass and looked at those three long mounds and tried to understand life; deeper still, to fathom death.

column2: She and her mother had agreed that there was "something." Now Kate tried as never before to understand what, and where, and why, that "something" was.
column3: She and her mother had agreed that there was "something." Now Kate tried as never before to understand what, and where, and why, that "something" was.

column2: Kate looked up to see Robert coming across the churchyard with his arms full of greenhouse roses.

Whether he believes his soul enters a cat and works back to man again after long transmigration, or goes to a Happy Hunting Ground as our Indians, makes no difference with the fact that he enters this world with belief in after life of some kind.

column2: We see material evidence in increase that man is not defeated in his desire to reproduce himself; we have advanced to something better than tom-toms and pow-wows for music and dance; these desires are fulfilled before us, now tell me why the very strongest of all, the most deeply rooted, the belief in after life, should come to nothing.
